column1: By Valerie Volcovici

column1: HUNTINGTON
column2: WV When Carissa Sellards talks to her West Virginia University friends about post-graduation plans
column3: one dilemma keeps coming up - whether to stay in their home state or strike out for more promising opportunities elsewhere.If recent history holds
column4: over half of them will either not find work or leave the state
column5: contributing to a brain drain of young talent that is pushing the state to try to reinvent its economy and break with a coal industry in long-term decline. ""Companies don't come here to invest because they only associate us with coal
column6: said Sellards
column7: a 20-year-old sophomore who addressed the state legislature when she was in high school about the lack of opportunities for young people in a post-coal economy.The often stark choices faced by Sellards and other young
column8: educated West Virginians underline the challenges awaiting Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton here and in other ""Rust Belt"" states if she wins the Nov. 8 election
column9: as most polls suggest she will.West Virginia is expected to vote decisively for Republican Donald Trump
column10: who has gained in recent polls and promises to revive the coal industry and put miners back to work by easing environmental restrictions and renegotiating trade deals to America's advantage. It is a message that has resonated with millions of older voters in other Rust Belt states facing declines in manufacturing jobs and feeling threatened by foreign competition.    But it largely rings hollow for college-educated millennials like Sellards
column11: who are seeking jobs in the service economy or technology sector.By contrast
column12: Clinton alienated swathes of West Virginia voters by saying earlier this year that ""we're going to put a lot of coal miners and coal companies out of business"" in transitioning to cleaner energy. Coal industry backers have long accused President Barack Obama of waging a ""war on coal"" by imposing tougher environmental standards.Clinton later apologized for her comment
column13: and has proposed a $30 billion plan to help revitalize coal communities. The plan promises to secure health benefits for former coal workers
column14: invest in new infrastructure such as broadband access
column15: and repurpose old mines and power plant sites.Clinton energy adviser Trevor Houser has said her challenge will be to help coal and other Rust Belt communities deal with economic realities rather than ""false promises"" of restoring dying industries.Beneath the nostalgic coal rhetoric
column16: West Virginia officials and grassroots groups have quietly started to focus on reversing the flight of college-educated millennials to help drive an economic revival. Of the 124
column17: 358 students who graduated from public higher education in West Virginia in the last decade
column19: 730 were working in the state in 2014
column20: a work participation rate of 47.2 percent
column21: according to a report released by West Virginia University's Bureau of Business and Economic Research on Monday. The state had the 11th biggest net outflow of college degree holders from 2007-2014
column22: according to the most recent U.S. census. One barrier to keeping graduates in state is a business start-up rate that is the lowest in the country at 5.1 percent in 2014
column23: the most recent year of available data.

column1: A Reuters analysis of national data shows a strong connection between migration patterns of college graduates and local start-up rates: Among the 25 states with start-up rates below the 2014 median of 6.8 percent
column2: 19 saw a net outflow of college grads between 2007 and 2014.The debate over West Virginia's economic future comes as its coal production this year hit its lowest level since the 1970s. West Virginia's energy sector
column3: which includes coal
column4: natural gas production and utilities
column5: account for 17 percent of the state's GDP but only 4 percent of employment. Coal industry employment plunged 53 percent between the fourth quarter of 2011 and the second quarter of 2016
column6: down from nearly 26
column7: 000 to just over 12
column8: 000. The government is the state's biggest employer
column10: with healthcare a fast-growing sector at 17 percent. In 2014
column11: West Virginia's real GDP grew 0.7 percent from the previous year compared to the national average of 2.2 percent. The state is one of a few whose population shrank over the past two years
column12: according to the latest national census. By median age it is the second-oldest U.S. state
column13: four years above the national average.    At the West Virginia University Institute of Technology's new campus in Beckley
column15: close to some of the state's coal counties
column16: officials hope to turn the struggling city into an innovation hub.

column2: sustainable tourism and health care

column7: he said. ""They are seeing that we have to change our own story.""

Although Clinton would struggle to regain popularity in Rust Belt states if elected

By David Lawder
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Twelve U.S. senators urged on Wednesday that a national security review panel reject Chinese aluminum giant Zhongwang International Group Ltd's proposed $2.3 billion purchase of U.S. aluminum products maker Aleris Corp.The senators asked Treasury Secretary Jack Lew in a letter to launch a review of the deal by the Committee on Foreign Investments in the United States and ""ultimately reject it"" on grounds that it would damage the U.S. defense industrial base. ""Zhongwang's purchase of Aleris would directly undermine our national security
column2: including by jeopardizing the U.S. manufacturing base for sensitive technologies in an industry already devastated by the effects of China's market distorting policies

column6: announced just over two months ago
column7: would give one of the world's largest makers of extruded aluminum products access to U.S. technology and customers
column8: which include Boeing Co and U.S. and European automakers that are increasingly turning to aluminum.It comes as another Zhongwang subsidiary is embroiled in a dispute over U.S. import duties amid broader trade tensions between the U.S. aluminum industry and China.

Each such closure further imperils our nation's ability to ensure a reliable supply of strategic materials in times of crisis
column4: they wrote.A Treasury spokeswoman declined to comment on the letter

column2: the DailyMail.com reported on Wednesday.The online version of the British newspaper said electronic devices are banned at the facility
column3: which separates men from women and treats a range of addictions related to cyber sex
column4: exhibitionism and anonymous sex and other acts. The facility was not named in the report.Reuters could not independently verify the report. Weiner could not be reached for comment.Federal prosecutors and New York police announced last month they were investigating Weiner following a separate report by the DailyMail.com that he engaged in sexually explicit cellphone and online messages with a 15-year-old girl from North Carolina.Weiner
column6: did not respond at the time to Reuters' requests for comment on the texting report but told the Associated Press last month that he had ""likely been the subject of a hoax.""

column1: An investigation into those messages also triggered a new FBI probe of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's emails
column2: as some of her emails were found on a device related to the Weiner investigation
column3: sources close to the matter said.Once a popular congressman
column4: Weiner resigned in 2011 after saying he had accidentally sent a lewd picture over Twitter. Two years later
column5: his campaign for New York City mayor was derailed after explicit photos he had sent under the pseudonym ""Carlos Danger"" to a young woman in Indiana surfaced.

column1: Weiner's wife
column2: Huma Abedin
column3: one of Clinton's top aides
column4: said in August she was separating from her husband after yet another scandal.Abedin's announcement followed a New York Post report that Weiner had recently sent photos of his boxer-brief-clad genitals - one while he was in bed with their toddler son - via Twitter to another woman.

column1: An attorney for Abedin could not be reached on Wednesday to comment on the DailyMail.com report. (Reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco; Editing by Bill Rigby)"
8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKBN12X2P6	Clinton leads Trump by 6 points
column2: same as before FBI announcement: Reuters/Ipsos	"

column1: By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Hillary Clinton led Republican Donald Trump by 6 percentage points among likely voters
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos daily tracking poll released on Wednesday
column3: the same advantage the Democratic presidential nominee held before an FBI announcement that reignited the controversy about her email practices.The Oct. 28-Nov. 1 opinion poll was conducted almost entirely after FBI Director James Comey notified Congress last Friday his agency would examine newly discovered emails that might pertain to Clinton's use of a private email server while she was secretary of state.Comey said he did not know whether the emails were significant and released no information other than that they existed. His announcement drew outrage from Democrats who voiced concern it would unfairly influence voters so close to next week's election. Trump and other Republicans seized on the news to revive questions about Clinton's credibility.

column1: Among 1
column2: 772 people who have either voted already or were identified as likely voters in the Nov. 8 election
column3: 45 percent said they supported Clinton
column4: while 39 percent said they backed Trump. On Thursday
column5: the day before Comey's announcement
column6: Clinton led Trump by 43 percent to 37 percent.In a four-way poll that included alternative party candidates
column7: Clinton led Trump by 8 percentage points among likely voters. Forty-five percent supported Clinton
column8: while 37 percent backed Trump. Five percent supported Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson and 2 percent backed Jill Stein of the Green Party.

column1: Other national polls have shown Clinton's lead shrinking over the past week. RealClearPolitics
column2: which averages most major opinion polls
column3: showed Clinton's lead had narrowed to 1.7 points on Wednesday from 4.6 points last Friday.

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted online in English in all 50 states. It had a credibility interval
column2: a measure of accuracy
column3: of 3 percentage points. (Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-golf-idUSKBN12X2M2	Wedge issue: Texas golf range offers Clinton and Trump targets	"
LONGVIEW
column2: Texas Looking for a way to help relieve stress in a heated political season
column3: a Texas golf course owner has given patrons the chance to whack their balls at large posters of the leading presidential candidates affixed to hay bales.In the Republican-stronghold of Longview
column4: where Alpine Target Golf Center is located about 120 miles east of Dallas
column5: Democrat Hillary Clinton has been the overwhelming target for patrons' golf balls.""Hillary Clinton is taking it a lot on the chin
column6: owner Mike Williams said on Wednesday of the promotion that started about a week ago.

column1: The Trump poster has suffered little damage
column2: Williams said
column3: noting ""he is still in great shape.""

column1: (Reporting by Todd Yates; Editing by Andrew Hay)"
